snippet.textDisplay: The potential of what this trilogy could have been is what hurts the most. I mean new characters new adventures and important roles for the best characters in star wars from the original trilogy. In the end we got three incredibly rushed films. Written and directed by different people with entirely different visions. Pushed forward by absolutely blatant corporate Disney greed over milking everything they can out of the series. The worst part is we will never see this trilogy’s full potential. Carrie isn’t coming back. Harrison ford will never do another one of these films. There is no retconing and entire poorly written trilogy. Say what you will about the prequels. They were made with a single creative vision and climaxed in Revenge of the Sith which was quite honestly a great film. Not only that they sparked a generation of expanded universe masterpieces like the Clone Wars series and video games like the Force Unleashed. Imagine trying to make expanded universe crap for this sequel trilogy. Just imagine trying to do that. There is no scope to the stories. No real originality. And if star wars is anything it should be an original take on the hero’s journey. That’s what made star wars special. It’s a plot that is as old as time told with this incredible expansive universe.

snippet.textDisplay:
If you want to know what the fans want, look at Knights of the Old Republic games. Look at the best episodes from the Clone Wars. Look at Jedi Fallen Order. Hell even look at Rouge One or star wars theory's the Vader Fan Film.

People want interesting NEW and expensive LORE. The orginal 6 movies are like gospel or your foundation and you just work off them. It's not difficult. Just look at all of the EU. Look at games like Republic Commando or the force unleashed. No bullshit retreads that don't make sense (JJ) or a smack in the face to fans (RJ).

We don't have to chose between to hot or to cold. If they actually try something new that respects previous lore and rules, most fans will accept it no matter what but when they come up with lazy bullshit. Yeah fans will hate it forever and never let it go.

snippet.textDisplay:
This is so disingenuous. "Fan Service" / "Die Hard Fans" does not equal repeating the old movies...... All "the fans" want is to have a movie with a plot that doesn't shit on the established history of the franchise.


There's so much room to be creative in that, but what we got was .... a plot that completely invalidates the meaning of the entire trilogy of trilogies. For instance, books/cartoons/the first 6(7) movies all were consistent with the fact that The Emperor was the big baddie and that Anakin was the "chosen one" to bring balance. That culminated at the end of Return of the Jedi with Darth Vader going back to the light side and kill the Emperor....


So.... doing something like .... bringing back the Emperor is *not fan service*. Why? It completely ruins the significance of what happened in the first 6(7) movies. If the Emperor is still alive then the whole Anakin / Luke / Vader's / etc. whole storyline was meaningless.

As far as Rian 'doing things', again, "fan service" does not equal repeating the old movies. Rian wasn't criticized for trying something different, but for doing different things that simply make no sense that unnecessarily created issues.
Examples:
- Flying a ship through the "big baddie" Star Destroyer - This essentially ruins every space battle ever. Why would they bother with all of these space ships if they could just make "missile" ships and fly through the bad guy ships?
- Marry Poppins (errrr Leia) - Creates new force ability to fly through space *AND* then never does anything else with her powers? Odd.
- Luke Skywalker - This is the most ridiculous of all - He takes a character that has been the most positive force in the Star Wars universe and turns him into a whining/grumpy old man drinking blue milk from alien tits. Are you f'ing serious? Completely inconsistent with this character's 40+ years of history... And no, I"m not saying he needs to be the star, but surely there's a better way to work him into the final movies....

The biggest travesty of all of the new movies is the ridiculous amount of pandering to demographics in a transparent attempt to make the movie appeal to as many people as possible. I have no issues with anyone, but when you do things purely to pander, it detracts.....
snippet.textOriginal:
This is so disingenuous.  "Fan Service" / "Die Hard Fans" does not equal repeating the old movies......   All "the fans" want is to have a movie with a plot that *doesn't shit* on the established history of the franchise.  


There's so much room to be creative in that, but what we got was ....  a plot that completely invalidates the meaning of the entire trilogy of trilogies.  For instance, books/cartoons/the first 6(7) movies all were consistent with the fact that The Emperor was *the* big baddie and that Anakin was the "chosen one" to bring balance.  That culminated at the end of Return of the Jedi with Darth Vader going back to the light side and kill the Emperor....   


So.... doing something like .... bringing back the Emperor is *not fan service*.  Why?  It completely ruins the significance of what happened in the first 6(7) movies.  If the Emperor is still alive then the whole Anakin / Luke / Vader's / etc.  whole storyline was meaningless.

As far as Rian 'doing things', again, "fan service" does not equal repeating the old movies.  Rian wasn't criticized for trying something different, but for doing different things that simply make no sense that unnecessarily created issues.  
Examples:
  - Flying a ship through the "big baddie" Star Destroyer - This essentially ruins every space battle ever.  Why would they bother with all of these space ships if they could just make "missile" ships and fly through the bad guy ships?   
  - Marry Poppins (errrr  Leia) - Creates new force ability to fly through space  **AND** then never does anything else with her powers?  Odd.
  - Luke Skywalker - This is the most ridiculous of all - He takes a character that has been the most positive force in the Star Wars universe and turns him into a whining/grumpy old man drinking blue milk from alien tits.  Are you f'ing serious?  Completely inconsistent with this character's 40+ years of history...  And no, I"m not saying he needs to be the star, but surely there's a better way to work him into the final movies....

The biggest travesty of all of the new movies is the ridiculous amount of pandering to demographics in a transparent attempt to make the movie appeal to as many people as possible.  I have no issues with anyone, but when you do things purely to pander, it detracts.....

snippet.textDisplay:
You ask "is this what we wanted" and the answer is No. We wanted nostalgia, but in the spirit of Star Wars, not literally retreading the same ground. The spirit of Star Wars is not irritating Mary Sue chicks and useless side-kicks (the hated Jar Jar notwithstanding). The spirit of Star Wars is a Hero's Journey, from "Zero to Hero" as Disney's Hercules puts it. And if Kennedy wanted to succeed and not just push a feminist agenda, should would not have looked for directors to write the kind of stories she wanted to see. She would have adapted the books that Star Wars fans already liked.


Now, it's obvious that Mark Hamill and the rest were too old to make direct adaptations of what happened after Return of the Jedi, but sticking closer to the story of Jacen and Jaina Solo and Ben Skywalker, would have been much better than the nonsense we ultimately got. Besides, they basically ripped it off with their Kylo/Rey set-up from Force Awakens, anyway. You don't make your hero the ultimate power in the universe, because then it's not a triumph when she overcomes evil. And if you want to subvert expectations, you make Jacen/Kylo our ostensible hero (Star Wars is really a story for young boys after all) and overpowered chosen one, and have him turn to the Dark Side at the end of the first film in the trilogy, or part-way through the second. At which point Jaina/Rey becomes the hero and has to stop her much more powerful brother.


That's a hero's journey. That's tragedy and pathos. That recreates the themes of the first trilogy. Familial conflict, betrayal, good triumphing against evil despite the odds being in evil's favor. Not this idiotic Mary Sue fantasy. And also you get to bring Boba Fett back, which is cool.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think now that the three films are out and we can take a step back, as much as I loathed the political pandering in TLJ, I have to admit that TFA is where the story problems began, because absolutely no new ideas (besides Finn being a defector) were present in that movie. This meant that in order to create a new and unique set of films, Rian had to consciously move the film away from just being a OT rehash. He did a poor job of it IMO, and pandered too much to current moment politics which detracted from good storytelling. With a mess of a middle act, JJ, rather than attempting to embrace some of these drastic changes, just simply reverts back to default.

Why did they ever think having two different directors writing a trilogy AS THEY GO was a good idea? Seriously man, as if you'd expect this to be cohesive when it's obvious they had no overarching story beats or lore for these characters developed prior to shooting Episode VII.

snippet.textDisplay: NO Star Wars fans wanted the same thing over and over again - this is where critics are getting the ‘toxic fandom’ wrong. We wanted new SW that was consistent with previous world lore and expanded / continued the story into new realms. That’s why we had years of expanded universe content created by fans that Disney cancelled out. We wanted continuity. The Last Jedi didn’t do that it contradicted, erased, ignored and rewrote everything before - that’s where it failed. It was basically a SW film made by someone who had never seen one before and was guessing and getting it really badly wrong. It’s such a shame JJ had to try and fix it - he should have been given the full trilogy to make from the start. Heartbroken.
snippet.textOriginal: NO Star Wars fans wanted the same thing over and over again - this is where critics are getting the ‘toxic fandom’ wrong. snippet.textDisplay: I get the point that you’re making around the 6 1/2 to 7 minute mark here, But I think the underlying issue is that Johnson went so far overboard in his risk-taking and rewriting of characters and Skewing the mythology That it kind of made it impossible for JJ Abrams to succinctly make a narrative that was satisfying without  tons of exposition and retreading.  It was taken so far off course that they either had to keep going which would’ve made very few people happy or they had to try to bring it back to some semblance of Star Wars.  Ergo this movie was never not going to be a giant mess.

snippet.textDisplay: the problem with the last jedi isn't that it subverted expectations, its that it did it poorly and left us with a story going nowhere, not to mention it was over bloated and tonally inconsistent. so with the rise of skywalker making all these backtracks to supposedly fix the damage is an impossible and pointless job. all they had to do was plan out a compelling story for the three films before they started making them, they needed to have a story to tell, instead their focus was to churn out these ridiculous films as quickly as possible to make as much money as possible, an utterly soulless pursuit of money at the expense of a modern mythos that once inspired and united so many. what a waste!
